talk.start.para:
—Madam President, my question is directed to Senator Hill representing the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Minister, I would like you to clear up some of the confusion surrounding the visit to Australia of the Dalai Lama. Did you cancel your appointment with the Dalai Lama? Did the Deputy Prime Minister state that the government did not recognise religious visits? What, therefore, was the status of the foreign minister's meeting with the Dalai Lama? Were only spiritual issues discussed, or did the meeting cover non‐religious issues? Now that the Prime Minister has confirmed on the
AM
program yesterday that he will in fact be meeting with the Dalai Lama, can you explain in what capacity he will meet the Dalai Lama? Will it be a purely private meeting, and what will be the Dalai Lama's status—that of a religious leader?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para:
—Madam President, it is a little disappointing that the Labor Party seeks to make cheap political points from the visit to Australia of a highly distinguished spiritual leader in the Dalai Lama. We saw it with the
very inadequate shadow foreign minister, Mr Brereton. He was the first to go down this track when he went public and said that the Prime Minister should meet the Dalai Lama to apologise for him—a rather grubby little bit of domestic politics, I would suggest. That was followed by Mr Beazley who showed no leadership on this matter at all, and I regret to note that the ALP in this chamber wants to continue with this today.

answer.para: We welcome the visit of the Dalai Lama to Australia. As I said, he is a distinguished religious leader. I said the other day—you obviously didn't listen, senator—that I was pleased that Mr Downer had met with the Dalai Lama in that capacity, in meeting a spiritual leader.

talk.start.para: —What was discussed at the meeting?
—I actually wasn't present at the meeting, senator, so I can't give you full details of the discussion.
—Who was present at the meeting?
—Well, Senator, there was a public statement after the meeting. Why didn't you listen to the public statement?
—So you haven't been briefed on the matter?
—Mr Downer went public after the meeting and reported on it. So that was pleasing, Madam President. And I am pleased also today to be able to—
—No photographs, eh? He met him in the dark.
—I missed that, I'm sorry. I am pleased also that the Prime Minister will be meeting the Dalai Lama. I think that that is good.
—In what capacity?

—In a personal capacity, of course—in the same capacity that Mr Keating met him. That is an interesting point, Madam President. Although they seek to make cheap, grubby political points out of this visit at the moment, in fact the status of the visit and the level of recognition that is being accorded by our government were exactly that that was
accorded by the Labor Party during the Dalai Lama's last visit.

answer.para: So I regret this. It is a disappointing aspect to this visit, and it simply demonstrates that the Labor Party—peeved at having lost government—is not prepared to lift itself above this grubby level of domestic politics and recognise that this is a spiritual leader who should be respected in his visit rather than used in this way.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I ask if he is caught up by the statement made by Senator Schacht in the debate on the recent Telstra urgency motion in this chamber that the profit of Telstra went up 31 per cent between fiscal year 1994-95 and fiscal year 1995-96? Is there any substance for that claim at all?

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —Yes, Senator Schacht is quoted as saying that profit after abnormals had risen by 31.1 per cent and, indeed, he is correct. There would not be a company in Australia today that would mind being a sheltered workshop if its profit went up by 31 per cent.

answer.para: What Senator Schacht does not understand is that you do not use these sorts of numbers to make comparisons between years, because the whole point of abnormals is that they are one-off. Telstra itself conceded that this is not the right number to use for comparisons. Here is what Frank Blount said—and I hope you will take this down:

In some respects this figure is a little flattering, because it's about 30 per cent higher than last year. In fact there's been a turnaround of abnormals of about $770 million. Last year we were down more than $550 million because we made a superannuation provision. This year a change in our depreciation methodology has bumped us up by $200 million. The number you should use for comparisons year on year is profit after tax but before abnormals.

Telstra did not report that figure, but it can be calculated. Indeed, BZW, Senator Schacht's favourite investment bank, says that profit after tax before abnormals was $2.1 billion in 1994-95—up by two per cent, not 31 per
cent. According to BZW, overall a two per cent profit growth is not very encouraging.

So it is quite clear that Senator Schacht still has not the vaguest idea about how one measures profitability in the marketplace. It is very disappointing that he simply has not been prepared to do his homework on this or a number of other issues. As we know, he is still getting around to asking someone to do a ghost draft of his submission to the ABC, to the Mansfield inquiry. About the most he has been able to contribute to this debate so far is that he put out a press release on 1 September apologising for inadvertently referring to Donald McDonald as `Donald Donaldson'. He told the press to `please amend his statement'. He apologised for any inconvenience. That is a pretty good contribution to the ABC debate.

I was even more perturbed when I was surfing the Net the other night once again to discover that, when you look at Senator Schacht's home page, the last update is 22 February 1996. What do you find there? You find all sorts of goodies, Madam President. Senator Schacht's is listed in his capacity as Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, so time stands still for this lot. Senator Schacht says, `If you want to know what we've been up to, you can go to my home page and see the hot issues area.' What happens when you go to the hot issues area? You get one of the best one‐liners of all time: `Labor's reality versus John Howard's rhetoric. If you would like to have your say, click here.' You really cannot get much lower than that. He has not got time to update his home page; he has not got time to do any work on his ABC submission; and, he can't even get the name of the ABC chairman right. What is he doing? Why doesn't he go and see BZW and get a sensible briefing, and then he will have an understanding of this issue?

Just in case you might like to start doing a bit of research, what you will find, for example, on the issue of privatisation is that a good friend of yours, Nelson Mandela, has made a useful contribution on the subject. What he said recently was this: `Privatisation is the fundamental policy of the ANC and it's going
to be implemented.' That really says it all, does not it?

If only you would go and do your homework. I know it is difficult whiling away those long, lonely hours in opposition but, rather than twiddling your thumbs and playing pure politics, why can't you do some homework? Take a refresher course—or probably, in your case, a primary course—on the basic economics, and you will understand that Telstra's profit performance is not all that good.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister whether Senator Schacht's financial and economic expertise matches that of proven Labor governments' performance in the past?
—Madam President!
—Order! The question has to be related to the minister's area of responsibility and can only be answered by the minister—
—It is self‐evident but, since the opposition is so dumb, I thought I would spell it out.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. We had a primary question directed to Senator Alston from Senator MacGibbon about Senator Schacht that I had expected you to rule out of order. I expected you, at some time, to call Senator Alston to order during his answer. None of those things occurred.
—You took a point of order.

—I did not take a point of order. I would now ask you to rule the supplementary question out of order. It is not a supplementary to the non‐question asked earlier and I believe that no reasonable person could come to any other judgment than that the supplementary question is out of order and that Senator Alston should be asked to resume his seat.
—I believe the question is out of order in that it does not relate to government policy or the government's reaction to other policy or that it is within the minister's area of responsibility.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. At the estimates hearing on Monday you were forced to concede that you would allow appeals by those who are affected by your changes to the treatment of superannuation assets for out of work over‐55s. Could you confirm that where people could demonstrate that there are significant impediments to drawing on their super assets before the age of 65 you would allow them to retain the means test exemption for superannuation assets? What percentage of those who will be affected by this measure are likely to encounter significant impediments to drawing on their superannuation early? Minister, how will your backflip affect the anticipated savings of $225 million from this measure?

—The opposition had a great deal of opportunity on Monday to canvass this issue very thoroughly with the officials. There is no doubt that there are some people—the opposition was told they believe it is a very small minority—who cannot access their superannuation entitlements before the age of 65 because they are in a particular legal structure which prevents it. The officials made it quite clear to the opposition that measures would be put in place to protect those people.

—On a supplementary question, I ask the minister again: what percentage of those who are affected by the measure are likely to encounter significant impediments to drawing on their superannuation early—what percentage? I asked you what impact this would have on the anticipated $225 million of savings? I also ask you, Minister, is there any way that impediments to early access of superannuation can be incorporated into existing agreements? If so, wouldn't this effectively nullify your budget measure?

—This, of course, is a measure which does not come into effect until, I think, September next year. As a result, some of the details as to how many people there are precisely—the exact percentage—are not yet certain. The officials made it very clear that they believed it was a very
small percentage. I cannot at this stage add to that although when the department has a better view of the precise percentage we will be in a position to inform the opposition. Nevertheless, on the amount of savings that have been allowed for in the budget we have had to take an estimate of a very small percentage of people who would be affected by this.
—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate.
—Go for it, Winnie.

—I will. Opinion polls show us that there has been an overwhelming level of public support for the government's budget strategy. What other recent endorsements have there been of the government's economic strategy?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —A very good question, too. We are pleased to see the overwhelming level of public support for the government's budget strategy. It is not surprising because that is exactly what the public elected us to do. Just recently, it was demonstrated by the Morgan poll—I mentioned that the other day—which showed that 77 per cent of people, including at least 60 per cent of Labor supporters, rated the budget as higher than any of the previous Labor budgets. Sixty per cent of Labor supporters said that we were doing a better job on economic management than 13 years of Labor.

answer.para:
That is reinforced today by the poll that appeared in the
Australian
. I will just run through a few of these figures for the benefit of the Labor Party, in particular: best party to handle interest rates, the coalition by 44 per cent to 26 per cent; best party to handle taxation, the coalition by 40 per cent to 28 per cent

talk.start.para: —Tell us the figures for industrial relations.

—Best party to handle inflation, the coalition by 45 per cent to 25 per cent, Senator Ray; best party to handle the balance of payments, the coalition by 46 per cent to 21 per cent. Just in passing, I might
say, it says that the best party to handle the environment is the coalition, Senator Faulkner. That is a little closer but isn't it interesting that the public of Australia recognises that the new coalition government is even better at handling the environment than the Labor Party.

answer.para: This is important, Madam President, because it demonstrates that it is still the view of the Australian public that the policies upon which they elected us they wish to see implemented. In other words, the budget that we put down which took the hard decisions they endorse and they want to see passed in this chamber. That is critically important. Why is it? It is because people are still reflecting upon the failures of Labor and the consequences of those failures.

I remind you, Madam President, that, under Labor, general government debt increased from $17 billion in 1990 to $96 billion last year. If there had not been any adjustment in this budget it would have increased to $120 billion. That is what the people of Australia were not prepared to cop any more. That would have been an increase of over 600 per cent in just 10 years. In underlying terms, debt had increased by $69 billion in the past five years. This is the record of Labor that the Australian people rejected. It has a consequence because it means that 7.5 per cent of this year's budget outlays are going to meet the cost of debt that Labor ran up. We need to spend some $10 billion to pay for debt that could have been spent on much more worthwhile programs.

Michael Egan, the Labor Treasurer in New South Wales, even recognised it when he said recently that more debt now simply means bigger interest bills in the future and fewer dollars to spend on hospitals, schools, roads and other key priorities. That is what the people of Australia rejected at the last election. They wanted us to take a new direction and they wanted us to take the hard decisions. We have done that in this budget. Now they want this budget passed in order that the benefits that can flow from those hard decisions do flow, to the benefit of all ordinary Australians.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and refers to what one commentator described this morning as the utter shambles to which this government has reduced the portfolio of Aboriginal affairs.
—Not as big as the Hindmarsh Island issue.

—If you think it's a joke, I don't. Given that the full bench of the Federal Court has now unanimously ruled that the appointment of the Special Auditor on 4 June, without any prior consultation with ATSIC—and, as we found out last night, with anybody else—was beyond the power of the minister and, in fact, legally invalid, I ask: what action has the government taken or will it take in respect of the operations of the Special Auditor following the Federal Court's decision? What is the current financial liability of the Special Auditor to date to cover all its costs? Does the government still intend to saddle ATSIC with the bill?

answer.ministerial: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs
answer.speaker: Herron, Sen John

talk.start.para: —The government is considering the decision and obtaining full legal advice on its implications. We will be looking at the possibility of an appeal and at other options in due course. It would not be appropriate to discuss the matter further at this stage.

answer.para: In relation to the Special Auditor, the Special Auditor's role has been to examine the past compliance record of organisations proposed for ATSIC funding and to advise me on organisations which are not considered fit and proper to receive ATSIC TSRA funds. Normal September quarter grant funding arrangements continued in the meantime and further interim funding has been an option.

Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber at the present time.

—It would not be proper to comment further on that. In relation to the cost of the Special Auditor about which Senator Collins asked: the government expects special benefits from greater accountability applied to ATSIC processes in terms of
value for money. The cost of the Special Auditor increased because the scope and complexity of the Special Auditor process proved greater than first assumed. The total number of organisations requiring close examination was virtually double that contemplated, and the costs of the Special Auditor varied accordingly. The Special Auditor is being asked to stop his work in view of the Federal Court's decision, and the costs are therefore yet to be finalised.

—Madam President, I have a supplementary question: I am, I must say, delighted to hear that the government at long last is going to seek some legal advice on this issue. I am encouraged by that. Following the evidence that we took last night from the Office of Indigenous Affairs in estimates about the fact that they were `consulted' in terms of advice: is it a fact that the only advice that was received on this issue before you issued your ministerial direction from both the Office of Indigenous Affairs and the Attorney-General's Department was provided on the same day that the cabinet took the decision on 9 April?

answer.ministerial: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs
answer.speaker: Herron, Sen John

talk.start.para: —As I said previously, I do not intend to speak in specific terms on these matters because of the possibility of further legal action, and until such time as the government has received further legal advice. I can confirm what Senator Bob Collins said that the advice came from the Attorney‐General's Department and that officers from Attorney-General's were involved in drawing up general directions. Clearly, as I said, there is the possibility of further legal action. I do not intend making any further comment until that legal advice is available.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs too. Minister, irrespective of whether the government intends to appeal the decision or not, I would like to ask you on the principle: why should ATSIC pay what you told us yesterday in estimates was $830,000 so far? Why should they pay the cost of a ministerial action which has so far been found to be invalid?

answer.ministerial: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs
answer.speaker: Herron, Sen John

talk.start.para: —As I said previously, there is considerable benefit accruing to ATSIC through this process. As you may not be aware, Senator Kernot, at the estimates yesterday the number of organisations that were found—

answer.para:
Honourable senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! Just a moment, Senator Herron.

—About two-thirds of the way through the process, the Special Auditor found that 80 per cent of organisations were in amber or red category. So that process was extremely valuable. The evaluation prior to that was that it was about a quarter of that. So considerable benefits will accrue to ATSIC as a result of the process that was instituted.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, did you not also say under questioning at estimates that this amber category were really minor technical breaches. So I think you are overstating the benefits that you are claiming. But the question is still a philosophical one: $800,000 plus and the government has to pay costs to the New South Wales legal service. We have a $1 million spent here. Could it not have been better spent directly on services to indigenous people?

answer.ministerial: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs
answer.speaker: Herron, Sen John

talk.start.para: —It is true that there were considerable variations in amber: some were minor technical breaches but some were major breaches. It was a large volume. ATSIC's own estimation at the beginning was very small, that that should be so. When you are talking about relative costs, the Matthews report on Hindmarsh Island cost over $1 million and ATSIC contributed over a quarter of a million dollars to that. When you are talking about relative costs, Senator Kernot, you really have to consider the value that is obtained from expenditure of funds. I believe that there will be substantial value to ATSIC of these funds that have been expended, albeit that a court decision found on a technical matter that the decision to institute the audit was invalid.
—You don't even know whether the audit will stand up.
—Of course it will stand up.
—Legally, minister!

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. I refer to the anger and uncertainty created by your decision to increase the reef tax by 500 per cent, and the even greater uncertainty created by indications last night by the gang of five in the House of Representatives that a compromise position was being negotiated with the government. Is it not true that the Treasurer, Mr Costello, stated on 10 September that the government would preserve this measure `at all costs`? Has Mr Costello changed his mind and is this budget decision now being reviewed?
—Remember what you said yesterday morning at about 6 o'clock at estimates.

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —A quarter to six in the morning, if I remember rightly. I presume that the honourable senator is referring to the environment management charge; a charge that was first imposed by his former Labor government. I am sorry, Madam President, I do not remember it being referred to as a reef tax when it was introduced by Labor. When it was introduced by Labor, it was referred to as an environment management charge, but now you are on the other side of the chamber, politics call for a new definition. The budget—

answer.para:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Hill, answer the question, please. Ignore the interjections

—The budget did provide for an increase in the environment management charge by $5, which would lead to a $6 charge, which is less than half that which we charge for entry to other parks such as Uluru or Kakadu and is not far off what is going to be charged for entry to parks through commercial operators by the Queensland government under the budget it put down last week. That is consistent with the trend that we see in Australian governments looking for a better
sharing between the users of parks, natural resource values and the taxpayer at large. That is what we are seeking to do in this instance: to increase this environment management.

—I raise a point of order on relevance, Madam President. Senator Hill was clearly asked by Senator Cook: has Mr Costello changed his mind? Is the reef tax being reviewed? I would ask you to direct him to answer the substance of the question.
—He is certainly dealing with the topic. He has another two minutes in which to develop his answer. I think there is no point of order.

—Sorry, Madam President. I thought I heard Senator Cook talking nonsense about a gang of five or some such thing as that. Anyway, if they are not interested in what I have been saying I will simply say that the integrity of the budget will stand.

—I ask a supplementary question. Senator Hill has not answered the question; he has evaded the question. The question was: has Mr Costello changed his mind and is this budget decision now being reviewed? I ask you, Madam President, to direct Senator Hill to answer that question and, while he is, to not evade this question as well: could the minister assure the Senate that any government flip‐flops on this issue will not be at the expense of funding for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority? Can you answer both questions, Senator Hill, for a change?

—Mr Costello has not changed his mind. The integrity of the budget will stand and we will continue to fund adequately the preservation of the natural resource values and the conservation values of the Great Barrier Reef.

question.block.title: Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Alston. I ask the minister: can you indicate what has been the response after the announcement of the government's Bass Strait passenger vehicle equalisation scheme?

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para:
—Probably the Hobart
Mercury
said it all in its headline which was `Bookings bonanza'. Since the announcement of this scheme on 23 August, there have been an unprecedented number of inquiries to take up this new initiative. Bookings for sea travel across Bass Strait have gone up by 45 per cent. TT‐Line reported that more than 19,700 ticket inquiries had been made since the announcement of the subsidy. As former Premier Ray Groom said, in the 13 hours following the announcement more than 7,500 calls were made to TT's central reservations office in Devonport. This has been an enormously successful initiative to which Senator Newman was a prime contributor. It clearly demonstrates the superiority of our approach on this important issue.

answer.para: The scheme provides for a rebate of $150 for a single trip and $300 for a return trip in the peak holiday season, slightly lower rebates applying in other seasons to reflect the lower cost. The scheme will reduce a driver's net fare when sharing a standard cabin to a similar cost to that notionally incurred in driving an equivalent distance on a highway.

The scheme has been given the thumbs up by industry, certainly by the Tasmanian government—Premier Rundle and Ministers Cleary and Groom—TT‐Line and the chairman of the National Sea Highway Committee, Mr Peter Brohier. In other words, everyone who has looked at this proposal says that it is infinitely superior to the Labor alternative.

There has been some criticism, as you would expect from a carping, negative, going nowhere opposition. Of course, what they fail to recognise is that the funding for this proposal is not capped. It will be demand driven. The scheme therefore fulfils a key election commitment to Tasmania and represents an ongoing recognition of equity for Bass Strait travellers.

Labor's very second‐rate alternative approach to this was to put a very large bucket of money on the table in order to enable a second ferry to be built. That would make absolutely no difference necessarily to the level of cost of fares. It would simply be putting money in the pocket of a new owner. That is far from attractive to consumers.

break.para: Labor's funding would have miserably failed to cover future operating costs, would have provided no guarantee that travellers would have benefited from lower fares and would not have provided any competition. In other words, we are giving assistance where it is needed. It goes to the consumer; it makes travel more affordable. It is very much in line with an approach that is sensitive to consumer needs rather than simply the old Labor handout mentality.

I would have thought now that we have seen the reaction—universal acclamation from industry, from consumers—that the least that people like Senator Sherry should do is perhaps follow Senator Schacht's example and put out a corrective statement admitting that this is yet again another very successful budget initiative. As you would know, the recent Morgan survey indicated that our budget was the most popular since 1978. One of the reasons for that is that we very carefully ensured that consumers are the beneficiaries. We did that in Tasmania in spades, and the citizens of Tasmania are very, very grateful. They certainly will not appreciate your going around carping at the margins, making yourself even more irrelevant and simply not facing up to an infinitely superior approach.

question.speaker: Collins, Sen Bob

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, representing the Minister for Transport. Is it a fact that the Aviation Safety Authority formally, in writing, advised the aviation industry in May this year in respect of emergency locator beacons:

question.para: Aircraft owners are urged to continue to fit C91A or C126 ELTS emergency locator transmitters as this equipment provides an important means of saving lives and assisting search and rescue operations and will be required for the appropriate aircraft.

Is the minister aware that a number of aircraft owners—who have now contacted me, I might add—and purchased this more expensive and effective equipment, based on the written advice from the safety authority. Given what the government has now admitted in the Senate estimates—that the Minister for Transport issued a political direction to the
safety authority to downgrade both the effectiveness and price of the beacons determined by CASA—are those people who met the conditions, the written conditions, to fit the more effective and expensive beacons now entitled to be compensated?

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —I am sure Senator Collins appreciates that the detail of that question is not something that I would have before me. Quite clearly I would be prepared to get back to him but—
—I do appreciate that.
—Surf the net.

—Senator Cook says `Surf the net.' Yes, maybe it is worth a try when all else fails. But the trouble is, you see, that I have had about 12 hours of Senator Bob Collins in estimates committees over the last few days, and the last thing I would want to do is get out there in the dark of night and suddenly find Senator Bob Collins creeping up on me on a graphic which would probably make sure I got no sleep at all following that.

answer.para: I will take the detail of that question on notice, but there was one part that particularly struck me, and it was a classic example of how Senator Bob Collins's mouth runs away with him. The second part of that question was: was I aware that a number of aircraft owners had contacted him, expressing concern? Of course, the fact is that I do not know—and I would not know. I am not prepared to proceed on any such shonky evidence. If there are matters of concern that Senator Bob Collins wants to properly relay to the minister, I am sure he will do that in due course.

talk.start.para:
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I might add in passing that, if the minister cannot handle the heat in estimates, he should leave, by all means. While the minister is seeking this advice from the minister, can he give the Senate an undertaking that he will table in the Senate all of the communications on the question of downgrading the Aviation Safety Authority's requirements: all correspondence, memos and file notes on this issue that were passed between the minister's office—and, particularly, I might add, the senior adviser of
the minister—and the safety authority, directing the safety authority to change its decision on the standard of the locator beacons required.

—Once again, I think that even Senator Bob Collins understands that you cannot give those sorts of undertakings on the run. To the extent that it is possible to make certain material available that does not conflict with cabinet‐in‐confidence or any other limitations on the making of—
—A bit of a cover‐up here.

—I think you blokes invented the art of finding reasons for not disclosing documents, but we will approach the matter sensibly, we will take advice on what can be made available and, in due course, you will get whatever you are entitled to get.

—My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. Minister, voluntary carers of the sick, elderly and disabled often go unrecognised, yet they provide an extremely valuable service to Australian society and in fact save us billions of dollars. The Carers Association of Australia has commented on the initiatives in the budget which affect carers. Could the minister please outline these comments and expand on how the initiatives will assist carers and recognise the valuable role which they play.

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para: —Senator Sandy Macdonald is right in highlighting yet another area of the budget which has been very well received by the people of Australia. It is no wonder that the responses to polls such as the Morgan poll that Senator Alston was referring to a little while ago report that people are not ambivalent about this budget in any way: the highest majority since 1978 believe it is a good budget.

answer.para:
This is one of the reasons why the budget has been so well received. For many years the Carers Association of Australia was a voice crying in the wilderness, with the Labor government giving it little or no attention. It was a matter of some surprise to the coalition
that so little consideration was given to the plight of carers, because in a very practical sense they are providing a national effort which could hardly be duplicated by institutional care in this country. Even if it could, the cost to the nation would be enormous and the quality of the care could never match that of people who are giving care to those they love.

The role of the carer is one of the most undervalued in Australia, and it was certainly undervalued by the previous government. Carers go about their work in a dedicated and benevolent fashion without fanfare, without reward—and they are not really asking for that. They assist in the de‐institutionalisation of the sick and the disabled by enabling them to remain in the familiar surroundings of their home.

The national carers action plan is being fully implemented, and that demonstrates our real commitment to carers. The Carers Association of Australia, in October 1994, put out a report entitled
`Listen to carers: the many voices of care
. On its front page, that report said:
Carers are living lives of quiet drama, with little recognition or reward. Carers are angry, fed up and filling an ever increasing care gap. Carers are also exhausted, lonely, ill and poor.

It took a change of government before those needs were met in a substantial and meaningful way. I would like to incorporate in
Hansard
the press release put out by the carers association entitled
`Forgotten people' recognised in budget
. In that the executive director of the Carers Association of Australia is reported as saying:
. . . the fact that the Government will be establishing Carer Resource Centres sends a direct message to all carers that this Government cares about them.

She went on to talk about the various initiatives, such as increasing the number of respite days allowed for carers from 42 to 52 days a year, essentially recognising that carers are entitled to at least one day off a week. That is going to give them the opportunity for some sort of break. There is going to be an extra $36 million in the budget for additional respite care resources, which makes those things lock together in a very productive way.

Senator Chris Evans asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. I refer you to the recent decision by President Clinton to approve Food and Drug Administration laws, declaring that nicotine and tobacco is a drug subject to federal legislation. Why has the federal government not followed the US lead and lifted the schedule 7 exemption on nicotine and tobacco? Is it the case that the government has no intention of acting on this matter, as was claimed by government sources quoted in the Melbourne
Age
on 26 August this year?

The Government welcomes the move by the US President to further restrict the promotion and availability of tobacco products. In doing so, the USA joins many other countries in acting decisively to address the massive cost to society and the health of individuals caused by tobacco-related death and disease.

I am pleased to say that Australia remains at the forefront of tobacco control and indeed many of the initiatives announced in the Clinton package have already been implemented in Australia. The major effect of President Clinton's announcement is to list nicotine as a drug of addiction, thus enabling action to be taken to restrict advertising of tobacco products. For example, billboards displaying tobacco advertising will be banned within 1000 feet of schools. The package also limits tobacco advertising in magazines. In Australia, all forms of
tobacco advertising, including billboards and in magazines have been banned outright since 1 January 1993 under the Commonwealth Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992.

Currently in Australia, nicotine is listed as a poison in the Standard for the Uniform Scheduling of Drugs and Poisons (SUSDP) except when it occurs in tobacco which is prepared and packed for smoking.

The AMA and other health advocacy groups have called on all Australian Governments to follow President Clinton's example and to move to have nicotine in tobacco scheduled as a poison. The AMA has also been part of a coalition of health groups that has made a joint submission on this issue to the WA Poisons Advisory Committee, asking that it remove the exemption for tobacco products from Schedule 7 of the SUSDP. It seems the Opposition is now joining that call—but they seem to have misunderstood the effect of the recent US decision.

In Australia, as the Opposition is well aware, tobacco has been treated as a drug of dependence in the context of the National Drug Strategy (and its predecessor, the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse) since its inception in 1985. We do not therefore need to remove the exemption from Schedule 7 to enable us to address the harms caused by tobacco consumption in this country. Indeed, we have been able to achieve a tobacco control regime which is one of the toughest in the world without scheduling tobacco in this way.
Nonetheless, we are keenly awaiting the outcome of the WA Poisons Advisory Committee's deliberations and will examine their decision from a national perspective.

Given the achievements that have already been made and the continuing commitment of the Commonwealth Government, I am confident that Australia will maintain and build upon its reputation as a pioneer and innovator in the field of tobacco control.

speech.para: I would be able to comply with this direction by the next sitting day, but I am unable to comply with it by today. Following the extension that we granted and then the further extension that we granted last week when the matter was dealt with, we felt that the minister would be able to comply, because we had extended twice the very reasonable offer we had made. speech.para: As he would be aware, even the documents he has released have proved to be very valuable in the debate we have had in seeking to get to the bottom of this matter. It now seems to me that the minister is being unreasonable. Obviously we want to assist in this but we are being prevented, by this further extension, from using the documents in estimates to enable us to get at the truth of the matter.

talk.start.para: —Deliberate cover‐up.

—Well, I have.

—I take your point, Senator Faulkner. This is an issue that has gone on for some time. The previous government struggled with it. It is critical that this parliament, this Senate, get to the bottom of the matter and have the documents before us so we can respond appropriately. I say to the minister that I want to be reasonable, but he is stretching the patience of this chamber. I am not sure what we can do about it. speech.speaker: Faulkner, Sen John

talk.start.para: —by leave—I thought that was a most moderate contribution from Senator Woodley. I think senators have come to expect moderate contributions from Senator Woodley, because he would be entitled to stand up in this place and roundly condemn the Minister for the Environment and Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) who has been given ample opportunity to comply with an order of the Senate but has failed to do so.

speech.para:
Senator Woodley and others might take their minds back to the time when the Labor government was in office. If any minister came into this chamber and provided such an abject excuse as the one that Senator Hill has given, there would have been hours and hours of debate condemning that minister. It is true that we heard these sorts of sanctimonious lectures from Senator Hill time and time again
when he was in opposition, but of course his attitude in relation to the importance of orders of the Senate and the need for us to comply with returns to order has changed dramatically since he has occupied the executive wing of this parliament. On the path to the executive wing, he has had a Lazarus‐like conversion on these orders of the Senate.

I say to Senator Hill in relation to this issue: you may try to prevent these documents being tabled, but what is clearly occurring is that slowly but surely the truth is coming out. We have already had exposed through the documents tabled earlier by Senator Hill the fact that he completely ignored the advice of two of his portfolio agencies—the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the Australian Heritage Commission—and he also ignored the advice of the World Heritage unit in the Environment Strategies Directorate of the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories.

Through the estimates committee process, we have had the capacity to establish that a significant number of documents which have already been tabled, in response to the requests of Senate Woodley, refer to other documents that have not been tabled in this place. So the position that the Leader of the Government in the Senate has outlined on this matter stands in stark contrast with the position that he and other members of the opposition took before they were elected to government earlier this year. Every member of this chamber knows it and every reasonable and objective observer of this chamber knows that we have in this pathetic response from Senator Hill a clear case of utter hypocrisy and double standards. That is what this statement amounts to today.

I say to Senator Hill that he can run on his issue but he cannot hide. I can assure him that when these documents are tabled—I am sure Senator Woodley and other non-government senators will be very interested in them—the opposition will pay very close attention indeed to them. We will ensure that this order is complied with. This is a transparent—

talk.start.para: —Cover-up.

—How can you have a transparent cover-up? This is a transparent
attempt by the Leader of the Government in the Senate to stop these documents being examined through the Senate estimates committee process. That is what it is all about. It is a cover-up, and I can assure you—

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We gave Senator Faulkner leave to make a short statement. He has gone over his material three times already and is now on his fourth time around. Could you sit him down and cut off his statement, because he not making any progress whatsoever?
—The Senate gave Senator Faulkner leave to make a statement.
—A short statement.
—There was nothing about it being short.

—I am surprised that any senator would offer the word `material'. It is material that we are in fact after, it is material, Senator Panizza, that we have not got, and it is material, Senator Panizza, we are going to insist on getting.

speech.para: It is proper to point out how reasonable Senator Woodley has been about this. He has been far too reasonable. He should learn from this experience that, if you give this mob an inch, they will take a mile. They are playing you for a sucker on this issue, Senator Woodley. I know you intend to continue to progress this issue, but I make it very clear: so does the opposition.

proctext.para: That the sessional orders in force on 30 November 1995 operate up to and including Friday, 18 October 1996.

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para:
—This proposition does demonstrate the durability of those sessional orders and, of course, how appropriate they were. I note that it has now been some six months since the election and that some nine weeks of sittings have taken place and we are still operating under the old sessional orders. We agree with the
proposition that these sessional orders were of very high quality and they clearly served this parliament very well, but it is an extraordinary proposition that this government, after some six months in office and some nine weeks of sitting, is still working on those sessional orders. All I can say is that I can commiserate with Senator Kemp about how difficult it must be to get any degree of coordination within this government. After six months and nine weeks of sitting, we have not moved any further forward.

speech.para: The opposition has made it perfectly clear that it is prepared to cooperate, to assist the government in making sure this parliament functions effectively and to make sure that it performs its functions as it ought to in terms of scrutinising the actions of the government and passing legislation for the benefit of the Australian people in such terms as to allow all senators to participate effectively in the proceedings of this chamber.
We have also made it very clear that, as we see it, there is an overall package of measures that needs to be considered. We are still waiting for that package to be developed fully.

talk.start.para: —It is a big ambit.

—It is no ambit. Be clear about this: there is no ambit. The opposition has put a very reasonable proposition to you. We have made very clear from day one what our position is, and six months later we have not moved forward. I commiserate with you, Senator Kemp. It must be an extremely difficult job being the manager of government business in this chamber when it is so clear that no-one on your side wants to assist you to actually fulfil your function.

speech.speaker: Kemp, Sen Rod

talker.name: Senator KEMP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

talk.start.para: —I will just make a few brief remarks. I notice the assurances Senator Carr has given that the opposition wishes to cooperate and wishes to ensure the effective running of this Senate. We welcome that statement and we will look anxiously and eagerly to see whether it has substance.

speech.para:
In relation to sessional orders, perhaps it is worth putting on the record the nature of what
has happened so that people who may have listened to Senator Carr are not misled. We have some sessional orders which are working comparatively well. There is some experience in working those sessional orders, so the chamber itself is working well under those sessional orders.

Can those sessional orders be improved? The answer is yes. Is there a proposal to improve the sessional orders? The answer is yes. The proposal to improve the sessional orders has in fact been agreed to by every party in this chamber—the government, the opposition, the Greens, the Independence and the Australian Democrats. As far as I am aware, there is general agreement that we can improve on the current sessional orders.

So why haven't we got these new sessional orders? The answer simply is that the Labor Party is not prepared to allow the new sessional orders to come in without agreement on a range of other issues. If we distinguish the sessional orders from the other issues, there is complete agreement, as far as I am aware. You have loaded onto the proposal to bring in the new sessional orders a number of other issues and those issues, as you well know, have not been resolved at this stage.

The motion before the chamber is to continue with the sessional orders, which are currently being used in this chamber and which are currently working comparatively well. We would prefer to bring in the new sessional orders, which we think would be an improvement. But I wait for you, Senator Carr, to come around to my office or to give me a call and say that you want to speak with me. What I want to hear from you is that the Labor Party will now accept these new sessional orders, which you fully agree should be brought in. At that moment I will come into the chamber, I will move them and they will come in. As far as my own side is concerned, the cooperation I am receiving is excellent.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
