speech.speaker: Sherry, Sen Nick

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para:
(1)
That the Senate notes the Government's 1996‐97 Budget announcements of:

para.tab:
(a)
a phased‐in 15 per cent surcharge on all future tax deductible contributions made to superannuation funds by or for high income earners, effective from 7.30 Australian Eastern Standard Time on 20 August 1996;

(b)
the application of a 15 per cent surcharge on all those accounts without a tax file number;

(c)
the introduction of a 15 per cent surcharge to defined benefit funds, to unfunded or constitutionally‐protected superannuation schemes;

(d)
the introduction of a 15 per cent surcharge to golden handshakes;

(e)
the removal of the means test exemption for superannuation funds and roll‐over assets for people aged between 55 and aged pension age who are without recent work experience;

(g)
allowing employees earning between $450 and $900 a month the option of choosing between superannuation guarantee contributions or the equivalent in wages;

(h)
the introduction of an 18 per cent tax rebate for people who contribute a maximum of $3 000 to the superannuation fund or retirement savings account of a non‐working or low income spouse; and

(i)
the introduction of retirement savings accounts.

speech.para:
(2)
That the Senate refer the matters contained in paragraph (1) to the Select Committee on Superannuation for examination and report by the last sitting day in November 1996.
Firstly, in speaking to this motion, I am cognisant of the fact that estimates are due to meet. I certainly do not intend to take up all the time available to me in my contribution to this debate.

Motion No. 222 seeks to refer a number of matters to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. This is almost a unique select committee. It has operated for six years; in itself, I think that is a unique characteristic. However, it is widely recognised not just in this place but in the wider financial sector, particularly amongst people who have an interest in superannuation, as being a committee that has made an effective contribution to the superannuation debate in this country. I do not say that because I was a member of the committee for the first three years of its life: I say it because, under the chairmanship of Senator Watson who has been the chair of the committee for the last three years—

talk.start.para: —An excellent chair!

—Yes, an excellent chair, and the Labor opposition were pleased to support his being reappointed to that position. As I say, this committee is almost unique in the annals of Senate select committees in that there has been a broad spirit of bipartisanship in its operation, and it has been recognised as having produced an extremely good set of reports that have usually been listened to by government. So it is an important committee.

break.para: As to the issues, there is a range of matters relating to the budget announcements in respect of superannuation that are being referred by this motion to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. I will run through some of those issues and outline why Labor has taken a decision to refer these matters to the committee.

On the first issue, that is, the 15 per cent surcharge that has been introduced in the budget to apply to superannuation contributions for high income earners as defined, there has been a lot of debate. I do not know whether Senator Allison saw the estimates proceedings last night, but we spent about an hour and a half trying to determine what is a tax and what is a surcharge. For the purpose of the government's accuracy, we have referred to it here as a surcharge, but it is in fact a tax, a new tax.

When we look at page 10 of the budget document for the Treasury portfolio, I find it fascinating that Treasury itself refers to it as an increased tax on superannuation. We find it interesting that Treasury documents refer to it as a tax. Even though we pressed Senator Short somewhat on this issue, when we attempted to ask the tax office people last night for the definition of a tax, amazingly they were not allowed to give us one. We must be the first country in the world where the tax office has been prevented by its minister from being allowed to answer the question of what is a tax and what is a surcharge. There was just no answer.

Also, when we put this question to Treasury, its officers were not prepared to define what is a tax and what is a surcharge. As I said, we must be the first country in the world where the tax office and Treasury cannot decide what is a tax and what is a surcharge.

This is an important issue as the government went to the last election with absolute commitments to the effect there would be no increases in taxes and charges, but this is one big tax. Last night we asked Senator Short whether it was the biggest increase in revenue—it is approximately $500 million a year—in the budget. In fact, it is the biggest new tax we have seen for some time, despite
the now Liberal government's protestations about it not being a tax.

At this point in the debate on this matter I want to say that Labor supports this measure. But that does not mean that there is not a range of concerns about how it will be implemented. Senator Short has been telling the world that I am responsible not only for this new surcharge—as he called it—being called a tax, but also for a range of concerns that are being raised about the administration of this new measure.

talk.start.para: —You are the Senate's super scaremonger.

—He accuses me of being a scaremonger. I am flattered that I am responsible for all of the concern that is being expressed out there in the financial community. I will read into the record a range of comments that have been made. There are 23 pages here, and this is just the tip of the iceberg. These comments have been made by a range of independent and distinguished people in the financial sector about their concerns on the issue of the administration of this measure.

break.para:
The Society of Certified Practising Accountants—no doubt I get on the phone to them, Senator Short, and tell them, `Do what Labor wants you to do'—condemned the surcharge for being inequitable, complex, costly, inefficient, creating uncertainty and conflicting with other government policies. They went on to say that the surcharge will cost as much to administer as it is expected to collect in additional revenue.
Mr Butler of Sedgwick Noble Lowndes noted that the government should be re-examining this tax surcharge because it looks to be producing results which may not be expected.

Mr Geoff Carmody, a Director of Access Economics—again, Senator Short thinks I get on the phone to Access Economics and push a line to them that they immediately adopt publicly—says that the disincentive effect of this application of the surcharge would be large. He suggested that the best way to tackle the problem would be to tax accumulated superannuation contributions when they are paid out at appropriate progressive tax rates.

We have a quote from Mr Hayes of the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. Is this someone I get on the phone to and urge to make public statements? He said that whoever developed this change has no concept of the practical implications and the problems which it will present. Professor David Knox, a former Liberal adviser on superannuation, has been appointed as a member of the government's new advisory committee that has been set up to examine the problems associated with this new tax, as a consequence of the budget announcement. He said that the tax system for super is so complicated that most people don't understand it, and this tax makes it more complicated.

I think the best quote of all comes from a person who is widely acknowledged in this chamber for his expertise in tax matters. Unfortunately, he is a senator who was passed over for the front bench—either ministerial or parliamentary secretary ranking. This quote is from Senator John Watson, Senator Short's colleague. We understand that he is no colleague of the Treasurer, Mr Costello, who, being his usual arrogant self, dismisses anything Senator Watson has got to say. Senator John Watson said:
The heaviest burden of administering the budget tax—
he does not call it an surcharge, he calls it a tax—
would fall on the so‐called accumulation fund of workers. The budget policy has built a complex web for super.

Senator Short had the gall to accuse me and Mr Beazley of allegedly having some sort of difference of opinion. We don't. The shadow ministry have made a decision on this matter. What about the split in Liberal Party ranks? Senator Watson, the very distinguished chair of the superannuation committee, was criticising this measure. Senator Watson is so concerned—

talk.start.para: —He has left the country!

—Yes, he has left the country—but not for this reason. Senator Watson is so concerned that, at the meeting of the Senate committee on superannuation last week, he agreed with the Labor initiative
that these measures should be referred to the committee for examination.

break.para: It is true that the government have set up an actuarial advisory committee to look at the details of this surcharge measure and the golden handshake matter. However, the government point blank refuse to accept that there are major concerns about the administration of this matter. It is quite clear that the government have locked themselves in. They refuse to listen to reasoned argument; they refuse to listen to submissions from the broader financial community that is concerned about this matter. These are not just our concerns—

talk.start.para: —That is untrue, and you know it—absolutely untrue.

—If the select committee recommends that the method of administration should be changed, I hope you listen. The purpose of referring this matter to the committee is to have full public hearings with proper submissions on this matter.

break.para: We asked last night at the estimates committee hearings—Senator Allison might also like to know this—whether this actuarial advisory committee document would be made public. Senator Short could not give us any assurances that it would be made public. That is not a critical issue, but it is important. Senator Short might like to enlighten us this morning. We did not get much enlightenment last night, but this morning he may be aware of what is happening in that regard.

Last night we raised the issue of the golden handshakes measure, which applies from budget night. People have left work and received a golden handshake, but there is no definition of a golden handshake in the budget papers. It is true that this actuarial committee is to look at it, but we have people contact us who have left work, having received a significant sum of money. These people have spent the money—they have paid off the mortgage of their home; they have made financial commitments—and they do not know whether they are going to be hit by this golden handshake tax. This tax may be legitimate, but it applies from budget night and there is no definition of what constitutes
a golden handshake. That is raising a series of broad concerns in the community.

A range of other matters arise. There is no doubt that we will have to use tax file numbers for the collection of this new 15 per cent surcharge tax. It does apply to defined benefit funds or constitutionally protected superannuation funds.

We have the removal of the means test exemption for superannuation funds for people over the age of 55. This issue has attracted a great deal of correspondence. I would like to take the credit for encouraging the thousands of people who are over the age of 55 who are very concerned about this new measure announced in the budget—but I can't, unfortunately. There is a great deal of legitimate concern about this measure. We have a provision to allow the opt out from superannuation of people earning between $450 and $900 a month. That raises a range of concerns.

Superannuation is to be removed from the Industrial Relations Act as an industrial issue. Who will monitor this? Half a million Australians, when wage negotiations take place, could be faced with a fait accompli: if you want a wage rise, take it out of your superannuation. This is a complex issue, but a very important issue to hundreds of thousands of Australians. We have the introduction of an 18 per cent tax rebate for people who contribute to a maximum of $3,000 to a superannuation fund or retirement savings. We have the introduction of retirement savings accounts. We have raised a range of concerns about the introduction of retirement savings accounts.

talk.start.para: —A pay‐off to the banks.

—My colleague interjects. I will not allege that at the moment but I would say that there are some suspiciously close associations between the current government and the big banking sector on a number of issues. This is one of them. I think I referred to them cuddling up to the banks. I noticed that the day after Mr Costello contemptuously and arrogantly dismissed a media release of mine he decided not to continue with the monitoring of bank fees and charges.
It is another interesting indication about the level of influence of banks on this issue.

break.para: There are a range of concerns about RSAs, most importantly—not exclusively—that it is a guaranteed low return product. That is incredible. There is no doubt—the banks make it clear and the government makes it clear—that it is a low return product. You get less money when you retire if you put your money into an RSA. The government assures us that this is voluntary but there are a range of problems with the voluntary application of RSAs.

There is a compelling case for what is recognised on both sides of the chamber as a committee which has done its job well to deal with and examine publicly a range of issues. In our motion we have not attempted to embellish it in any way with any rhetoric. It is a straight referral to the committee for full examination and public consultation. We have not even attempted to correctly refer to this surcharge as a tax. We have adopted the government's so‐called definition of this new charge. It is our wish to help the government—

talk.start.para: —They need a lot of help.

—They do need a lot of help—they are so sensitive on this matter. We have set very tight reporting dates. We propose that all these matters come back for reporting by the end of November. As you would be well aware, Mr Deputy President, by the time this matter is passed—and I hope it is passed today—there will be two or three weeks for advertising and receiving the submissions and we have only until the end of November. The Democrats, I understand, are proposing to make it even tighter in a number of areas.

break.para:
Nonetheless, it is a good committee; it is a committee that can report back expeditiously on these issues. And there is a need to report back expeditiously because we are not wanting to delay government budget measures. What I find fascinating, if Senator Short claims we are attempting to delay, is that when we asked Senator Short about the date for the legislation—Senator Allison may care to look at the transcript of the estimates last night—we found that the legislation on most
of these measures will be introduced this year but is not going to be passed until next year. So how can we possibly be accused of delaying? What we want is the proper committee, a committee recognised for its expertise, chaired by Senator Watson, a Liberal colleague of Senator Short's, who supports us.

talk.start.para: —A very fine colleague.

—Exactly. A very fine comment. I hope you acknowledge that Senator Watson supports our position to refer this matter to the Senate select committee. I hope you will agree with Senator Watson. Senator McGauran was there too, if you want verification of his support. They support the referral of this matter. There are very important issues. Everyone is concerned about their retirement income. Superannuation is a mainstream issue. There should be a very full examination and public consultation with expeditious reporting dates on this matter.

break.para: I reiterate that we are not interested in using this as a mechanism for delaying the budget. We are not interested in that approach. I have given that undertaking on a number of occasions; and I give it again. We support this new tax. We want to see it collected despite the fact that it was not in the Liberal Party's election manifesto at the last election. Where was their reference to a half a billion dollar a year new tax? The shadow minister has taken a decision on my recommendation and on the recommendation of our leaders to support it but there are very substantial concerns about the administration of it—the costs and the use of tax file numbers.

The tax applies from budget night, but it is not going to be collected until next year. The funds have to collect it in the meantime, not knowing what the law and regulations are. It really is an interesting, unique almost, approach in regard to what could be argued is a level of retrospectivity—although I do accept that governments have to make announcements on budget night with respect to a date, and legislate afterwards. There are some practical problems if they don't. Do not accept it on golden handshakes. I think there are some real problems with the operative date for golden handshakes.

We will have a good look at this at the select committee. I am sure the committee will operate effectively. It is going to be a tough timetable—the toughest timetable for referral of any matters on superannuation. We are pleased to pledge our cooperation with the government and particularly with Senator Watson, the chair of the committee. We are pleased to pledge our cooperation to try to resolve as many of these issues as expeditiously and as amicably as possible.

speech.speaker: Short, Sen Jim

talk.start.para: —What we have heard is the outline of a simply outrageous, obstructive political stunt by an irrelevant Labor Party. What Senator Sherry is attempting—
—You are not good at getting personal, Jim.

—I am not getting personal about you but I feel fairly passionate about your party, Senator Sherry. The impact of what Senator Sherry is attempting to do is to prostitute the normal processes of this Senate and, in so doing, he is running a very considerable risk of doing considerable damage to the very committee that has such a high standing and a high integrity and for which he professes to share that feeling—I am sure he does—namely, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

speech.para: I will come to the detail in a moment. My first question to Senator Sherry: why is he proposing to expose it and its high reputation to such a risk? I will come back to the reasons why I hold that view very strongly in the course of the remainder of my remarks. I note that, yet again, Senator Sherry has professed that Labor supports the policy decision of the government in the budget to impose a surcharge on high income earners so far as their superannuation contributions are concerned. What nonsense for Senator Sherry to say that!

The whole thrust of what Senator Sherry and the Labor Party are doing is to sabotage the decision. He wants to sabotage this decision. All this talk about supporting it is absolute nonsense. It is simply not true. The Labor Party want to maintain the inequity and the unfairness in the superannuation system that they built up over their 13 years in office which gave quite outrageous concessional
benefits to the high end of town, the high income earners, at the expense of the middle and lower income earners who, of course, constitute the huge majority of contributors and who will not in any way be impacted on by the decision of the government.

The range of superannuation reforms announced by the government in the budget will result in a fairer superannuation system which is more competitive and, very importantly, a more efficient superannuation system. The reforms will benefit families; they will benefit women; they will benefit low income earners; and they will benefit Australians in or near retirement. Families and women will benefit particularly from the rebate on spouse contributions, which will allow a contributing spouse to receive an 18 per cent rebate for contributions made on behalf of the low income earning spouse.

Low income earners and women, particularly those working part time or with broken employment patterns, will benefit from the policy to provide employees with the opportunity to negotiate the payment of additional wages and salary in lieu of superannuation guarantee contributions. That measure enables people to make a choice better suited to their financial position and their family and personal circumstances. The reason why so many doubts are being raised by the Labor Party about this one is that it involves giving Australians on lower incomes a choice—a choice which Labor would never be prepared to give them because `choice' is a dirty word in the Labor lexicon. Labor believes that it is Big Brother government that knows best how people ought to be able to use their resources; therefore, Labor governments limit choice, which is precisely what they have done.

Low income earners and women in particular will also benefit from the introduction of retirement savings accounts. These represent a simple, low cost, low risk superannuation product best suited to casual and part-time employees, and those who currently have multiple small superannuation accounts. Individuals will be able to nominate these accounts to receive their superannuation guarantee contributions and to amalgamate existing small superannuation accounts. This was an
election undertaking; in fact, it has been in our policy for a long time. Overall, it has been very widely accepted and welcomed.

I will go through some more of these details. Let me say early on in my remarks that the main reason why the government is so opposed to this motion moved by Senator Sherry at this time is that it is premature. He is wanting to refer to a parliamentary committee—the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation—for consideration matters for which there is not yet in the parliament any legislation. That may well be the appropriate committee in due course to look at legislation in this area.

Senator Sherry interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Senator Sherry is saying that Labor accepts the policy proposal but that there is an awful lot of devil in the detail and he wants to go into all of that. That is fine. He can do that, but he does not know what the devil in the detail is at the moment because there are no bills. There is no legislation before the parliament as yet. That is going to be produced, hopefully, into the parliament before the end of this session. It is going to be produced after wide ranging consultations that the government is presently engaged in.

speech.para: We are also seeking expert advice to ensure that the implementation measures for the policy decision are introduced in a manner that is efficient, that is equitable and that is as cost‐effective and minimum cost as possible. That consultative approach encompasses—and Senator Sherry does not seem to appreciate this—a very wide range of issues. We are seeking public submissions on the requirements that will apply to public savings accounts. We will have a discussion paper out on that matter for people to consider.

We have established an actuarial advisory committee which has also sought submissions but which does not have to report to the government until the end of October. That is a right and proper time to give it time to do its important work, because it is to advise the government on the most equitable application of the surcharge to defined benefits schemes and unfunded and constitutionally protected schemes. It is also looking at the golden
handshake issue that Senator Sherry raised in his comments. We fully accept that there are technical issues that need to be looked at there.

The Australian Taxation Office, along with the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, the Privacy Commissioner and superannuation industry representatives, is engaged in a program of extensive consultation to discuss the development of efficient and effective mechanisms related to the administration of the surcharge. There is also to be a joint tax office, ISC—Insurance and Superannuation Commission—and relevant industry body steering group to jointly manage the development of the systems, procedures and approaches necessary to implement the surcharge.

What the opposition is seeking to do here, with its now premature reference to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, is to duplicate without any significant benefit, and at potential significant cost, work that is already being undertaken by the government with all the important and relevant stakeholders who are concerned with this matter. It is obvious—at least I think it ought to be obvious—that the opposition cannot object to the fundamental fairness and benefits that will flow from the government's initiatives. Yet Senator Sherry seems to be so desperate to make a political point out of superannuation. That is a tragedy.

It really is a tragedy because for years we have had an essentially bipartisan approach to superannuation. We have had our problems along the way with what the previous Labor government proposed from time to time. But, in a spirit of bipartisanship, we have worked with the former government to produce a united, if you like, parliamentary view on superannuation for the simple reason that, if you do not do that and are all over the place in terms of division in the parliamentary ranks on this, then you create even more confusion and concern and instability in the system, which is very damaging to contributors and particularly to those approaching retirement. So I think it is regrettable that Senator Sherry is making a political point out of superannuation at the moment, particularly
when he claims to be supporting the overall policy objective.

What we have here, I am afraid, is another example of empty words from the opposition about seeking to reinstate stability, certainty and confidence to superannuation when the opposition's continued campaign of scaremongering is doing irreparable damage to community confidence in superannuation. This misinformation about the government's policies appears to be part of a concerted campaign which goes back well before the budget, as I have said.

Senator Sherry has made various dire predictions about what the government was or was not going to do in terms of superannuation. None of his dire predictions have come to pass—and never were going to come to pass—yet many Australians spent many sleepless nights prior to the budget on the basis of Senator Sherry's quite unwarranted scaremongering assertions. I am sure Senator Sherry is hoping he can use the committee to undermine or defeat these measures—not on the grounds of their equity or the choice that they offer members, because that is precisely what they do. These measures produce a fairer, more equitable superannuation system for Australians. Rather, what he is trying to do is to undermine or defeat them on the spurious basis that implementation is unnecessarily burdensome or impossible. That is simply not correct.

What we inherited as a government were highly complex, costly administrative arrangements that make up our superannuation system. That complexity occurred almost entirely during the 13 years of Labor rule, between 1983 and 1996, for a variety of reasons. Complexity was added to complexity, layer was added upon layer, and we are at the stage now where most Australians really have the most enormous difficulty—in fact they find it impossible—to understand the superannuation system, what it is about and what it means to them. All of that occurred during Labor's 13 years in office. It had 13 years to provide a stable and an equitable superannuation system. It failed lamentably to do so. Indeed, its actions led to the quite contrary result.

break.para: The surcharge, which is the main basis of the government's superannuation proposals, will involve changes to administrative procedures. Almost all the administration involved in the implementation of the policy will be handled by superannuation funds and the Taxation Office. Contributors and employers will see virtually no impact on them of the administrative procedures required to implement the policy decision.

Superannuation funds will have only two obligations: firstly, to report information about the member and the amount of contributions made to the member's account during the year; secondly, to deduct an amount from the affected member's account, which amount will be notified to them by the Australian Taxation Office. Senator Sherry gave notice of this motion before we had the very extensive discussions with the taxation and Treasury officials in Senate estimates last night. I hope that, as a result of those discussions in the Senate estimates committee last night, what is involved in an administrative sense was made clearer to him. It is much less of a burden on superannuation funds than he, or they, might have imagined.

As I said, the new procedures will not affect contributors at all. They will impose some burden on the funds—we have always acknowledged that—but we have implemented them because, firstly, we want to have a fairer system and, secondly, we want to introduce that fairer system and administer that fairer system in a way that does not impose additional obligations and burdens on either employers or contributors.

If a member rolls over his or her benefit to a new superannuation fund, any existing liability to the superannuation surcharge will be transferred to the new fund. If a member withdraws his or her benefit from the superannuation system, any existing liability to the superannuation surcharge will be transferred to the member. There will be appropriate review mechanisms available to deal with any dispute in relation to the super surcharge liability either by the superannuation fund or by the member. The main point of criticism that has emerged, and which I fully accept—

talk.start.para: —This is the first time that you have said that.

—I accept that criticism has been levelled at the proposed administrative arrangements for the surcharge. I have been consulting, I would venture to say, much more widely than Senator Sherry has on this matter and across a much wider cross‐section of stakeholders. But I do think that several of the important criticisms that have been levelled are misguided because of a lack of understanding at this stage.

break.para: It is claimed that the surcharge will result in increased administrative costs by superannuation funds, which will be borne by all members, not just those who have high incomes. That fails to take account of the fact that the information a superannuation fund will report to the tax office is no different from the information the fund should already maintain as part of its normal operations. It is information it should already have, apart from one significant element, and that is the tax file numbers of members. It is also information that is already required by law to be given to the majority of superannuation fund members each year.

There are also potential benefits in the administrative sense from what we are proposing to superannuation funds in that upgrading of administrative systems and improvements in administrative arrangements now are likely to lead to substantial cost savings in the future. For example, the use of tax file numbers will ultimate simplify superannuation fund administration.

Another claim is that the surcharge goes too far in requiring data to be collected for all superannuation members whereas only a small group eventually pay the surcharge. However, no‐one has yet demonstrated to the government a better approach to the collection of the surcharge than the one that has been announced. I say that despite the extensive consultations that have taken place, not just by me but more particularly by officers of the ATO, the Treasury and other officials concerned. All of us have been very heavily involved in this.

The approach we have adopted has several advantages, including that it reduces the
opportunity for people to avoid the surcharge, and it places a negligible burden of compliance on employers and employees. It has been suggested to the government that employers should play a larger role in the collection of the surcharge. We dealt with that in estimates last night, at least to some extent. I certainly do not agree with this view, nor does the government.

Whilst employers may know an employee's salary and wage level for the purposes of taxation on a PAYE basis, an employer would not have information on a person's taxable income, nor should they if they are receiving income outside their salaried position. But an employer would not have information on a person's taxable income, including other non‐PAYE income, personal reductions and rebates. Further, a mechanism such as has been suggested as an alternative—basically, the PAYE mechanism—would place a considerable administrative burden on employees and employers, and that would contrast with the existing arrangements which will minimise the burden on those groups.

Another area that has been expressed as a concern is how the surcharge will apply in relation to defined benefit funds and unfunded schemes. Some people have argued that this will involve substantial complexity and perhaps herald the demise of such schemes. I think that view is unfounded, but, as I have already mentioned, an actuarial advisory committee with very high level experts, headed by the Commonwealth Government Actuary, is at the moment looking at these matters and will be advising the government on the application of the surcharge to defined benefit and unfunded superannuation schemes—and one or two other elements as well: for example, as I mentioned, the golden handshake issue. On the basis of the committee's work to date, as I understand it, there is every probability that they will
recommend practical solutions to these problems.

There are many other things that I could go on about in terms of the detail, but that really masks the main point that I want to make, and I want to make it very importantly to Senator Sherry. I think he is not prepared to listen, but I hope that the Democrats may
listen to what I am saying. We are not opposed to—indeed, we support—the parliament having the opportunity to consider the detail of what we are proposing. But it can only do that when it has legislation to consider. That legislation, I hope, will be in the parliament by the end of this session. The consultative process is continuing, there are time lines on the conclusion of all of that, and we want to have as thorough, extensive, comprehensive and meaningful consultations as possible with all the stakeholders. Only then can we really draft the legislation and feel confident that we have met the points of all those stakeholders in framing the legislation.

What the government is saying is: sure, let us have a look at all of this, but you can only do it when you have got the bills. What are we going to do? If we accept this motion today, we will do two things. First, we will run the very considerable risk of major confusion, with the superannuation committee running a parallel set of consultations and inquiries to those we are doing in government now. Second, we will go through all of that process, and report; then the bills will come in and you will want to do it all again. That is a very odd way of going about things. It does not bear any relationship to logic, and Senator Sherry's motion today is not logical. It is purely a political operation, because he wants to obfuscate on this issue.

There are deep divisions within the Labor Party on the question of whether they support the principle or not. Senator Sherry says that they support the principle, but have you ever seen a situation before where an opposition has said, `Yes, we support the principle of this, but there is so much in all the detail that we might knock it out.'

talk.start.para: —I didn't say that.

—Senator Sherry is setting it all up to reject, and he is doing it because he is captive to a group in the community which wants to protect the quite outrageously high degree of concessionality which exists for the high income earners in this country at the expense of lower and middle income earners.

break.para:
Let us have a look at all of this in terms of the detail. But let those in the Labor Party not
come into this chamber with their hands on their hearts, saying, `Oh, yes, we support this principle of greater equity and fairness, but we are going to then have a look at every way to scuttle it and undermine it because we think there is the devil in the detail.' Let us look at the detail but let us wait until we get the detail. We do not have the detail at the moment. You will not have the detail until the bills are introduced. I hope that the bills will be introduced by the end of this session. That is our objective. I would then envisage—

talk.start.para: —If they are not, you will have some trouble.

—That is true. I would envisage that, over the summer recess, the bills will lie on the table. The appropriate parliamentary committee, which may well be the superannuation committee, could look at the bills—actually have something in black and white in front of them to look at. They could report back to the parliament at the start of the autumn session next year, which I think starts at the beginning of February. So the bills can be given proper consideration by the appropriate committee and then come in here and be considered by the full Senate on an eyes open basis. You cannot do that if you do not have the legislation to look at.

break.para: It is for that reason that, on behalf of the government, I am very strenuously opposed to this motion today. It runs the risk of doing great damage and causing great confusion, duplication and additional cost. It will not achieve anything that the more logical process will not achieve. In fact, it runs the risk of actually frustrating that proper process of consideration which is traditionally the way in which this Senate has operated, and that is by examining the bills when they are available.

For all of those reasons, let me conclude by saying that we want the parliament to give appropriate consideration to the detail concerning this matter. The parliament cannot do that until it has the bills. We undertake to do everything we can to achieve this.

talk.start.para: —This is new.

—No, I have told you this before. We have undertaken to do everything
possible to have those bills introduced into the parliament by the end of this session. It is a very tight timetable, but we will undertake to do everything we can to ensure that so that the detail of the bills can be looked at over the recess, as is the normal way of progressing and considering legislation in this chamber. In that way the matter can be debated properly and legislated early in the autumn session, hopefully, of next year—and if not the autumn session, then certainly the budget session, because certain important aspects of the legislation have to be in place by the start of the next financial year.

break.para: That is the timetable we are proposing. We think it is a logical timetable. It is normal due process that we are suggesting should be followed. Senator Sherry's motion cuts right across all of that. For that reason, the government is strenuously opposed to this motion.

speech.speaker: Allison, Sen Lyn

talk.start.para: —The Democrats support Senator Sherry's motion, but I wish to move amendments which have been circulated in my name and which I understand the opposition is likely to support. I move:

speech.para: Omit paragraph (2), substitute:

(2)
That the Senate refer the matters contained in paragraph (1) to the Select Committee on Superannuation for inquiry and report.

(3)
That the committee report on paragraphs (1)(a) to (f) by the first sitting day in November 1996.

(4)
That the committee report on paragraphs (1)(g) to (i) by the first sitting day in February 1997.

I want to start by saying that we believe it is possible for a review of these very substantial measures to be undertaken by this committee in advance of the legislation. Although I am a new member of the committee, I understand that in the past it has been quite common for this committee to deal with matters that are not already in legislation or proposed legislation.

para.break: My amendment seeks to change the report‐back date for the items (1)(a) to (1)(f) of Senator Sherry's motion, which deal with major budget taxation and savings measures worth in the order $600 million in a full year. I think it is appropriate that the superannua tion committee give priority to these measures and completes its inquiry with sufficient time for the legislation, if any, to be dealt with by the Senate this year.

speech.para: The Democrats have made their position clear on the general principle of the 15 per cent surcharge on high income earners. We have long advocated a more equitable taxation system for superannuation, with greater equity between high and low income earners. The measures announced by the government do not deliver that but, in our view, they at least are a significant step in that direction.

It is the method chosen by the government which raises serious implementation issues which I believe need to be examined. This can be done in a short, sharp inquiry, to determine whether the scheme can be improved to allow the government's tax initiative to then pass.

The inclusion of superannuation assets in social security means tests for mature aged beneficiaries between ages 55 and 65 is an issue which causes us some concern. My colleague Senator Woodley has asked a series of questions of Senator Newman in relation to this issue and I have to say that her answers have been less than satisfactory. A committee inquiry is, in our view, an appropriate means of finally getting the answers to the questions that Senator Newman keeps avoiding.

We acknowledge that the other matters—items (1)(g) to (1)(i) were important aspects of the coalition's superannuation policies. Consistent with long standing Democrat process, we believe it is important that such policy changes be subject to a public report by the superannuation committee.

Senator Short has said that this reference is obstructive and a delaying tactic. But as the government does not expect to have the legislation on these matters debated by the Senate this year, I suggest that it is appropriate to give the superannuation committee a reasonable time frame to look at these major policy issues in some detail and to allow for debate on these matters early in the next session of parliament.
Amendment agreed to.

para.emphasis: The speech read as follows—

speech.para:
This bill proposes changes to the Industry Research and Development Act 1986 which make the
research and development tax concession a better value program for all Australians, both by stopping unintended use of the concession, and making the administrative procedures better suited to the needs of industry.

Access to the concession is to be confined to a reasonable period after the research and development activities have been conducted. This means that the tax concession program can return to its rightful focus of encouraging new research, new development, rather than encouraging consultants to plow through years of company accounts looking for a tax sweetener for their clients. The scope of this gravedigging is so extensive that these measures are expected to result in revenue protection totalling $235 million over the next three financial years.
Other improvements to the registration process, such as advance registration and registration of activities, also encourage companies to direct their creativity towards new technologies and markets.

The bill also validates overseas research and development decisions and internal review decisions taken outside the mandatory time periods prescribed by the Principal Act. This validation is quarantined to the effect of the mandatory time period, and will work to confirm the deductions of companies affected by these decisions. Amendments are also made to ensure that such invalid decisions are not taken again in future, without undermining the mechanisms built into the legislation to ensure that companies receive decisions in a timely fashion.

A number of changes have been introduced to bring the administration of the research and development tax concession into line with the self assessment principles of taxation administration. These include reducing the obligations of the Industry Research and Development Board prior to registering a company, and introducing the ability to set fees by regulation in relation to applications and requests to the Board.

This bill represents a huge boost to the integrity of the research and development tax concession which is long overdue. I refer you to the Explanatory Memorandum to the bill for a more fullsome description of their changes and their necessity to the responsible administration of Commonwealth revenue.
I commend this bill to the Senate.

—
SENATE RURAL AND REGIONAL AFFAIRS AND TRANSPORT REFERENCES COMMITTEE INQUIRY INTO THE IMPACT OF ASSETS TESTS ON FARMING FAMILIES' ACCESS TO SOCIAL SECURITY.
Government Response to Second Report—Social Security assets tests (September 1995)

para.emphasis: Introduction

interject.para: On 30 June 1994 the issue of assets tests affecting farming families access to Social Security benefits was referred to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee. On 24 August 1995 the issue of assets tests affecting farming families access to AUSTUDY was referred to the committee. On 31 August 1994 the two references were combined.

The Committee conducted hearings through late 1994 and early 1995, and the Committee's first report dealing with AUSTUDY was presented in
March 1995. This response is to the second report dealing with the assets tests applying to Social Security which was presented in September 1995.

The principal areas on which the recommendations were made by the Committee were the application of hardship provisions, the operation of the pension loan scheme, improving the understanding of both customers and staff of options available to farm families, the valuation of assets and inter‐generational transfer of farm assets.

The Government is establishing a Special Rural Task Force to review the impact of the Social Security assets tests to ensure farm families are not disadvantaged. In particular, it will look at how the assets tests affects farmers who wish to retire on or from the family farm and pass it on to their immediate relations who are drawing their primary income from it, those who are unable to sell their property due to market conditions, who remain on relatively small or non‐viable land holdings on which they cannot generate income beyond the age pension limit, or who are unable to subdivide and sell their land due to government restrictions.

The Task Force will examine the detailed operation of the assets tests and hardship provisions. As part of its work, the Task Force will examine each of this Committee's recommendations. A response to all the Committee's recommendations will then be provided once the Task Force has completed its review.

para.emphasis: COMMITTEE RECOMMENDATIONS AND THE GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
(a) That applicants for social security payments under the hardship provisions for Jobsearch or Newstart Allowances should no longer be required to offer their property for sale.

interject.para: Response: Noted. The matter will be referred to the Rural Task Force.

para.emphasis: (b) That, as a matter of utmost importance, the Department of Social Security collect specific data on farming families.

interject.para: Response: Noted. The matter will be referred to the Rural Task Force.

The Department of Social Security principally collects data necessary for determining a customer's eligibility for payment and the rate payable. To collect data outside of this purpose would generally be in breach of the privacy provisions. Furthermore, it would be costly to implement, collect and maintain the additional data and would require specific system enhancements to store and analyse this data.

Data on occupation for Family Payment customers is available for all claims lodged after 1 January 1994 and for particular groups of Family Payment customers reviewed at the end of each year. However, there still remains a significant number
of pre‐existing Family Payment recipients for whom occupation is unknown. It would not be cost effective to review all Family Payment customers primarily for the purpose of seeking occupation data, particularly as this information is not essential for payment. However, if there is some need to review the entire Family Payment population in the future, the Department of Social Security will collect occupation data at that time.

This issue will be further explored by the Special Rural Task Force with the involvement of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Research Economics (ABARE) who can advise of other methods of collecting the data. This would ensure that farming families who are not currently receiving a Social Security payment will have data collected from them, providing a more complete overall picture.

para.emphasis: (c) That the Commonwealth Government increase significantly the liquid assets threshold used to determine eligibility for family payment under hardship provisions.

interject.para: Response: Noted. The matter will be referred to the Rural Task Force.

para.emphasis: (d) That the Commonwealth Government clarify the definition of liquid assets under hardship provisions for family payment. In particular, the Committee considers that the Government should specify the status of those liquid assets essential for the continuing operation of the farm business enterprise.

interject.para: Response: Not Supported.
The definitions for liquid assets under the hardship provisions for Family Payment are provided in the Social Security Act and state:

"liquid assets"
, in relation to a person, means:

para.emphasis:
(a)
the person's cash; and

(b)
the person's shares and debentures in a public company within the meaning of the Corporations Law; and

(c)
any amount deposited with, or lent to, a bank, building society, credit union or other financial institution by the person (whether or not the amount can be withdrawn or repaid immediately); and

(d)
any amount due, and able to be paid, to the person by, or on behalf of, a former employer of the person; and

(e)
any other readily realisable assets of the person;
but does not include an amount that is a qualifying eligible termination payment for the purposes of Subdivision AA of Division 2 of Part III of the Income Tax Assessment Act.
. . . ..a person's liquid assets are taken to include:
(a) the liquid assets of the person's partner; and
(b) the liquid assets of an FP child of the person.

interject.para: To ensure that potential applicants under the hardship provisions fully understand which liquid assets which are exempt, hardship forms will be reviewed to ensure that this information is available in a clear and accessible manner to the customer.

However, to attempt to specify every liquid asset essential for the continuation of the farm enterprise would remove the flexibility to assess each customer on an individual basis and according to each customer's circumstances. This provides for a more flexible approach for farmers claiming under the hardship provisions.

para.emphasis: (e) That, given the Committee's findings on the social and economic impact of the assets test on farming families' access to family payment, the proposed amendment, moved in committee of the whole stage of Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), should not be supported.

interject.para: Response: Supported

para.emphasis: (f) That, as a matter of priority, the Minister for Social Security review legislative and administrative procedures applied to determine eligibility for pensions under hardship provisions in order to ensure that farming families are not disadvantaged.

interject.para: Response: Noted. The matter will be referred to the Rural Task Force.

There are already a range of measures in place to lessen the impact of the assets test on farming pension customers. The effect of these can be demonstrated by the fact that 74% of farmers are paid under the pension income test rather than the assets test.
The following concessions under the assets tests are in place to assist farmers.

.
Where a farm is transferred to a family member, the value of wages foregone by the family member is allowed when determining the amount of assets to be maintained under the `gifting' provisions under the Social Security assets test. This beneficial treatment only applies to the transfer of farming property.

.
The total aggregated value of a person's farm‐related liabilities can be offset against the total aggregated value of the value of the person's farm assets. For non‐farming clients, the value of individual assets can only be reduced by the value of a debt that is secured by that particular asset. This concession was introduced in recognition that the value of farm assets had commonly depreciated at a faster rate than the debt over the asset had reduced (especially in times of high interest rates).
The report noted three areas of concern in respect of the assets hardship provisions. The Government's response to each of these is as follows.

para.emphasis:
.
Deemed Income on Unrealisable Assets

interject.para: The deemed income (when applied) is the lower of 2.5% of the property value, the commercial lease value, or the amount of rent that could be reasonably be expected to be paid by the family member operating the farm. When a family member is running the farm, it is usually either the commercial lease value or the rent from the family member that is assessed. The calculation of the reasonable rent amount takes into account half of the family member's and their spouse's income that is over the relevant Additional Family Payment income test limit ($21,000 if the family member has no children). A telephone survey of the Department's hardship assessors has identified the most common reason for a farmer's pension claim being rejected under the hardship provisions is because the level of their available funds is well above the `severe financial hardship' threshold. It was asserted that it would only be in extremely rare cases where a person would be rejected under the hardship provisions due to the level of deemed income applied in respect of the farm assets.

para.emphasis:
.
Gifting Provisions

interject.para: It appears that the Committee has confused the issue of gifting and inter‐generational transfers of farms as an issue within the assets hardship provisions. A farmer who is unable to receive a pension under the normal assets test because they have gifted assets may still be entitled to a pension under the hardship provisions if the person is suffering severe financial hardship that is not a direct consequence of gifting assets, or where the person is suffering severe financial hardship and could not have reasonably known that they would need to claim an income support payment at the time of the `gifting'.

These categories, therefore, exclude access to the hardship provisions for those who gift money to divest their available funds, and those who gift assets that were producing levels of income equivalent to the maximum applicable rate of pension. Farmers who transfer farm properties are treated under the hardship provisions in the same way as if they still owned the property.

para.emphasis:
.
Sharefarmers & Partnership Issues

interject.para: It appears that the separate issues of the administration of the hardship provisions and the treatment of partnerships and sharefarmers under the normal assets test have been confused as being one issue. Partnerships and sharefarmers are treated exactly the same way under the hardship provisions as other farmers.

The differing treatment of partnerships and sharefarmers is under the normal assets test when the farmer transfers the property to a family member. If the family member is employed for less than the average wage whilst working for the family business, the value of wages foregone by the family member whilst an "employee" of the pension claimant is deducted from the value of the property for the purpose of calculating the amount of deprivation to be maintained. This recognises the fact that many family "employees" have a commitment to the family business that outweighs individual financial concerns.

This deduction for foregone wages is generally not allowed for partnerships or sharefarmers, as it is recognised that the person's income is determined by market forces and not determined as a reasonable wage amount that would be paid in an employer/employee relationship. Having stated this, it should be noted that implementing this benefit for partnerships and sharefarmers as a longer term strategy has not been ruled out.

para.emphasis: (g) That, as a matter of urgency, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy establish an inter‐departmental committee to investigate and develop an integrated approach to the issues of retirement, managerial succession and assets transfer on farms.

interject.para: Response:
The Government will establish a Rural Task Force to examine this and related issues. An inter‐departmental committee would only duplicate the work of the Rural Task Force.

para.emphasis: (h) That, given the minimal interest in the Pension Loan Scheme, the Minister for Social Security investigate whether current arrangements should be modified or an alternative approach introduced in order to provide a viable option for those persons unable to qualify for social security payments because of the assets test.

interject.para: Response: Supported.

A revised Pensioner Loans Scheme (PLS) will be implemented from 10 July 1996. The revised scheme aims to encourage older people to improve their lifestyles by allowing them to access capital tied up in property by giving them an income stream repayable at any time, or from their estate.

It is a voluntary scheme that offers people who are receiving a reduced rate of pension under either the income or assets test the opportunity to use their real estate as security to obtain "a top up pension" in the form of an interest accruing loan. A person can withdraw from the scheme at any time. If someone withdraws from the loans scheme, they can elect to repay the amount owed at any time, or they can have it recovered from their estate.

This new loans scheme will be more flexible than the current scheme. The requirement that the person must have 70% of their assets as pensioner loan scheme assets has been replaced with the requirement that the person must have adequate assets to secure the loan. The revised scheme provides further flexibility by allowing applicants a choice in the size (up to a maximum limit) and the duration of payments made under the scheme.

para.emphasis: (i) That the Minister for Social Security investigate the feasibility of and equity issues associated with alternative approaches to valuing house and curtilage.

interject.para: Response: Noted. The matter will be referred to the Rural Task Force.

The Department of Social Security and consultants, Ageing Agendas, have examined some of the alternative approaches to valuing house and curtilage. The options examined included ceasing to exempt the principal home under the assets test (with an adjustment of the assets test thresholds); and changing the differential between the homeowner and non‐homeowner assets limits to reflect the average value of pensioner housing. A third option examined was to provide pensioners the option of deciding whether they were homeowners or non‐homeowners (with non‐homeowners having the value of their home included as an asset).

Ageing Agendas found in the review of the pensions income & assets tests, that there was a high level of opposition from pensioners to removal of the exemption of the principal home from the assets test. They stated that opposition often came from those who would theoretically benefit from this option, due to a fear the government would eventually cause people to make a choice between essential income support and their homes.

para.emphasis: (j) That the Department of Social Security publish and distribute widely specific information on social security payments and procedures relevant to farming families.

interject.para: Response: Supported.

The Department of Social Security is committed to providing a wide range of information relevant to farming families. The Department of Social Security contributes regularly to the Department of Primary Industries' Rural Book, which is a comprehensive guide to major Commonwealth government services and programs for people who live away from capital cities. The Department of Social Security also contributes information to the Department of Primary Industries database for the Countrylink telephone information service.

In addition, the Department of Social Security has recently co‐operated with the Department of Primary Industries in the development of a drought relief information package aimed at farming
families. The package provides information about Drought Relief Payment, hardship provisions for farmers and eligibility for Job Search Allowance, as well as more general Social Security information.

The Department of Social Security continues to liaise with the Department of Primary Industries about this project and the need for other products to be developed aimed specifically at the farming community, is continually being reviewed.

In addition, Social Security information products, such as You and Your Family—while not aimed specifically at farming families—provide broad, general information about eligibility, including income and assets test issues and encourage people to ring Social Security for further information.
Social Security regional offices also organise specific seminars to cover such issues when a need arises.

Research currently being completed by ABARE indicates that farmers are not aware of the hardship provisions. As suggested by the Committee, it is likely that many farmers who are precluded under the assets test are not aware of the hardship provisions and have not tested their eligibility. The Department of Social Security has recognised the need for an information campaign to increase the awareness of the hardship provisions, and is currently working on a strategy to achieve this.

para.emphasis: (k) That the Department of Social Security investigate whether procedures to identify persons who may be eligible to receive family payments, such as "trigger questions", should also be adopted for other payments.

interject.para: Response: Supported

The Department of Social Security reviews all forms on an ongoing basis. The use of trigger questions to ensure that the claimant receives all payments that they are entitled to is part of the Department's commitment to ensuring equal access to payments for all customers. The Department is also undertaking a simplification project, aimed at making claiming as simple as possible for customers. The use of such methods as trigger questions is currently being considered in that project.

para.emphasis: (l) That the Department of Social Security enhance the training of departmental staff in rural and regional centres in order to increase their understanding of the special circumstances of farming families.

interject.para: Response: Supported.

Farming families usually provide more complex details with claims and require in‐depth assessment. To enhance the skills of rural staff, Complex Assessment handbooks are used in assessing complex claims. Complex Assessment Officers, who are staff expert in assessing complex claims,
also offer a help desk to rural staff in dealing with complex assessments. This service may need to be publicised more to family payment staff.

The Department of Social Security has significantly increased the number of Financial Service Officers located in Social Security rural offices and also provides general training to counter staff. The Department will now look at opportunities to link up with local farmer representatives to assist with this training.

para.emphasis: (m) That the Minister for Social Security review all hardship provisions for social security payments in order to ensure that farming families are not disadvantaged. The Committee considers that this recommendation should receive urgent attention.

interject.para: Response: Supported.
The Government has established the Task Force to ensure that farm families are not disadvantaged by the application of an assets tests.

para.emphasis: Dissenting Report and Government Response

interject.para: A Dissenting Report was made by Senator John Woodley. While supporting the majority of the recommendations, he considers that the Committee should also have recommended that farmers wishing to retire on their farm or hand on their farm to the next generation, should be exempt from the Age Pension asset test.
The government recognises that these recommendations should be examined further, and will refer both to the Rural Task Force.

speech.speaker: Woodley, Sen John

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I have not had much time to look at the government's response to this particular report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee but it is to be commended for responding appropriately in a couple of instances, particularly in its response to recommendations G and H. As to my minority report, the government recognises that those recommendations should be examined further and will refer both to the rural task force. Again, I am glad that the government is doing that.

But I am a little disappointed that the government, in most of its responses, is simply saying that the matter will be referred to the rural task force. That response occurs under A, B, C, F and a number of other recommendations. Also, I am staggered to hear that the federal government is holding
two more major reviews into welfare payments for farmers because that is exactly what this response is to—a major review into welfare payments for farmers. We have to wonder if the government is actually deferring action on these issues.

I do not mind if the government bites the bullet on these issues and comes up with some action that will assist those farmers who, in many instances, need assistance. But, having taken part and, in some cases, chaired the inquiry—which took eight months, received 250 submissions and made a number of constructive recommendations to improve farm families' access to assistance payments—I am a little puzzled that we will now have another two inquiries and a reference to a special rural task force.

While I suspect that they are avoiding making decisions, I hope that the government, once having had these further inquiries, will act to expedite the assistance needed by primary producers in these particular instances. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

The tabling statement read as follows
—
REPORT ON THE REVIEW OF THE HEALTH LEGISLATION (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM) AMENDMENT ACT 1995

The reference to the Committee to monitor the implementation and operation of the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Act 1995 was originally given by the Senate following the passage of the Act in May 1995. The Committee continued with the reference following the election.

Whilst the Committee's reference was limited to monitoring the implementation and operation of the Act, many organisations took the opportunity of commenting on broader issues relating to private health insurance arrangements and the delivery of health services generally. The Committee will continue its inquiry into private health insurance arrangements by initially considering the following issues:

.
the relevance of the community rating principle in the light of developments in the health care area;

.
the effect of changes in the delivery of health care, including the fundamental question of public/private health sector mix and recognition of the shift to shorter hospital stays and to out‐patient care, technological developments in patient care, etc.;

.
the need to widen the scope of insurance products which can be offered to the public; including the adjustment of the product to changing circumstances;

.
the extent of regulation surrounding the industry and scope for reduction; the need to open the industry to greater competition in terms of new players and new products;

.
financing alternatives to the current system, including devising systems:

para.tab: to allow and encourage persons to take individual responsibility for financing of their future health care needs; and
to address the ageing of the population with subsequent growth in health care needs; and

break.para:
.
the applicability of alternative health care financing arrangements, for example, overseas social insurance models.
The Committee will also continue monitoring the operation of the Act as part of its ongoing inquiry.
The major objectives of the Act were:

.
to reduce the cost of private health insurance premiums and reduce the ever increasing cost of private health hospitalisation and treatment;

.
to provide better value for those who take out private health insurance;

.
to encourage a wider range of private health insurance products so that consumers are offered more choice about the type of cover which best suits their needs which, it was intended, would be achieved by enabling health funds to enter into contracts with hospitals and doctors.
To meet these objectives the Act provided:

.
organisations with the capacity to achieve efficiency gains through the implementation of casemix episodic payments for hospitals and day hospital facilities to replace the previous per diem payment system;

.
for high quality and value for money products through purchaser‐provider agreements with hospitals and doctors to eliminate unknown out‐of‐pocket costs; and

.
consumers with access to information about health insurance issues.

The major reforms in the Act were the introduction of purchaser‐provider agreements, whereby medical practitioners and health funds could enter into contracts for the provision of medical services rendered in hospitals and between hospitals and health funds. The Act also contained a variety of provisions which are intended to provide consumers with wider access to information about health insurance issues.

The evidence provided to the Committee demonstrated that the reforms have not been successful in meeting their objectives. People have continued to drop private health insurance cover, value for money with the insurance product offered continues to be questioned and information on health insurance, although improved, still needs considerable attention.

Whilst many hospital agreements have been signed with health funds, very few medical agreements have been finalised. Members of the medical profession continued to argue that they would not sign contracts because they could compromise the
independence of doctors and adversely affect patient care. It was suggested that contracts would introduce a form of US‐style managed care and lead to an abrogation of accepted clinical freedoms and the doctor‐patient relationship.
Doctors were also concerned at the oligopolistic domination of the market by health funds and the position the medical profession was in by being unable to negotiate in groups.

The Committee understood and appreciated the concerns expressed by the doctors, however, without many contracts having been signed the claims remained unsubstantiated. The Committee has therefore recommended that medical purchaser‐provider agreements should proceed, subject to the clear recognition in the contracts of the right of the medical profession to treat patients according to their clinical needs.

The Committee considers that doctors should be encouraged to jointly negotiate with funds by using the authorisation provisions in the Trade Practices Act. The Committee believes that it is essential, and in the interest of all parties, to ensure that a level playing field is established in the negotiating environment.

The Committee has also recommended that public scrutiny of purchaser‐provider agreements by consumers be provided for. In addition the Purchaser‐Provider Panel should be convened and that the Panel be provided with access to agreements as part of its monitoring role relating to the contractual arrangement process.Unlike the medical practitioners, many hospital agreements have been signed. However, similar arguments about the disproportionate powers of the funds were put by the hospitals about their negotiating of agreements with the funds. Hospitals were particularly concerned that country and smaller hospitals were disadvantaged in the negotiating process.

The Committee similarly understands the concerns expressed by the hospitals over their perceived limitations in negotiating in groups with the funds. However, the authorisation provisions of the Trade Practices Act which may permit group negotiations have not been tested. The Committee has recommended that the private hospitals should also be able to arrange joint negotiations by seeking authorisation under the Trade Practices Act.
The Committee received evidence from States expressing concern over aspects of the reforms contained in the Act. These concerns included:

.
that the reforms provide little incentive for health funds to enter into purchaser agreements with public hospitals;

.
that the policy of `equivalence' under the health insurance arrangements needed to be clarified;

.
that there was a perceived discrimination by funds against co‐located hospitals with funds currently unwilling to pay benefits;

.
that the effect of the current Medicare and health insurance arrangements is to encourage funds to direct their members to public hospitals for high‐cost treatments and where a patient's stay in hospital is likely to be longer; and

.
recognising `service innovation' in the health area for the purpose of paying benefits.

The Committee believes that the full impact of the reforms on State services in public hospitals may not be known for some time and that unintended consequences will need to be addressed by the Commonwealth Government in consultation with State and Territory Governments.

Turning to other issues relating to the Reform Act, the Committee considered it regrettable that the Aggregate Billing Advisory Committee had not been established, but recognised the willingness of relevant parties to now progress billing reform.

The Private Health Insurance Complaints' Commissioner has been in operation for nearly six months and had received over 600 complaints and general inquiries. The most common complaints received by the Commissioner had related to benefit entitlements, including level of cover, amount of benefit and lack of notification of changes to benefit entitlements; and waiting periods, in particular the pre‐existing ailment rule. The Commissioner suggested that the majority of complaints indicated that consumers do not understand what their policy covers or what they can and cannot claim from their policy. To date health funds have been co‐operative in attending to complaints quickly, without significant differences of opinion over remedial action.

The Commissioner also raised with the Committee concerns that her functions, powers particularly those of investigation and enforcement of recommendations, and duties were not as clearly and fully prescribed as they are for other similar dispute resolution bodies.

The Committee believes more time needs to be given to assess the types and quantity of complaints and the effectiveness of their resolution before making any firm recommendation as to any possible expanded role and powers for the Complaints Commissioner.

The Committee considers that the Complaints Commissioner's Office since its establishment has provided a valuable contribution to the health industry and its consumers. However, in such a short period of operation, the Committee believes it is too early to recommend an expansion to the Commissioner's role and powers.

The Committee also acknowledged the valuable role that documents such as the Private Health Insurance Administration Council's
Insure? Not Sure?
, and the
Private Patients' Hospital Charter
have played in informing consumers about private health insurance and their rights. However, the Committee is concerned that considerable confusion and ignorance remains widespread among consumers about private health insurance.

The Committee has recommended that insurance funds, medical providers, hospitals and consumer‐oriented organisations accept greater responsibility in the production of information for consumers, the format of this information, and in the availability and distribution of this consumer information. The Committee further recommended that consumer information brochures should be made available in languages other than English.

In respect of data collection, the new arrangements under the Act came into operation on 1 October 1995. From the evidence received, these arrangements appear to have operated smoothly. A major concern put to the Committee related to duplication in data collection at the Federal and State levels. The Committee has recommended that data collection at these levels be reviewed to ensure that any duplication of effort and resources is prevented. The Committee also recommended that the Private Hospital Data Bureau be established and that its role in the future collection and dissemination of data be included in the review.

speech.speaker: Tierney, Sen John

Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee on the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1995, together with the submissions received by the committee and transcript of evidence.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.
