Hansard
.
Leave granted.

The tabling statement read as follows
—
I table the report of the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee on the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1996.
The Committee recommends that the Bill be passed without amendment.

The Bill represents the first step in the process of changes to the education advisory mechanisms set out in the government's policy statement on higher education
Quality, diversity and choice.
The Higher Education Council and the Australian Research Council will continue as independent Councils, with similar functions, and with their membership unchanged, reporting directly to the Minister. The Councils will also take responsibility for promoting informed public debate and for granting financial assistance for innovative projects. There is also provision for the Councils to cooperate to provide advice to the Minister.

The National Board, which was established by former Minister Dawkins in late 1988, took some years to settle into its role, and appears to have had difficulties ever since gaining the full commitment of the various players in the education and training sector. While it has contributed to a cross‐sectoral view of policy matters, it has also been yet another layer of bureaucracy filtering advice from the expert Councils. The government's intention to replace NBEET with more streamlined advisory mechanisms has been on notice for quite some time.

The overall thrust of the evidence received by the Committee argued for the importance of portfolio advisory mechanisms being independent and publicly accountable. The requirement for independence ensured that government departments and agencies did not monopolise the advice available to the Minister. Accountability turned on the need for the activities of advisory groups to be open to public scrutiny, and in particular that their reports should be tabled in Parliament. The Committee has so recommended.

The Committee is of the view that diverse and independent sources of advice to the Minister and to the Parliament are to be encouraged, and that any future advisory framework should be expedited. The Minister has indicated that the government has already embarked on the relevant consultations with a view to ensuring that appropriate alternative advisory arrangements are quickly established..

The government will take advice from a range of bodies such as the Ministerial Council (MCEETYA), and will commission specific reports from appropriately tailored expert committees and from existing research organisations. The government believes that such an approach will provide flexibility, an efficient advisory process, and will avoid the necessity for retaining a fixed overarching structure through which advice must be filtered.

Public accountability will be achieved through the requirement that reports commissioned by the Minister will be tabled in Parliament. Accountability will also reside in the State and Territory Parliaments, especially for the schools sector. The Committee acknowledges that there will be an interim period of adjustment to the proposed new arrangements, but this is no more than the standard impact of structural adjustment. Schools, universities and training colleges will not be impeded in their day to day work during this interim period.

Legislation for the Higher Education Council and Australian Research Council will be introduced in the 1996 Spring session of Parliament, once the government has had an opportunity to examine the responses to its Discussion Paper.
I commend the report to the Senate.

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para: —I believe this report by the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee to be quite important. Many will not see it as being important. Many will say that the abolition of NBEET is only a small budgetary item, at some $6 million. I note that Senator Tierney has had his remarks incorporated. There is no doubt in my mind that he is, quite properly, embarrassed. He has every reason to be embarrassed. I believe that Senator Tierney does know something about educational matters, unlike, perhaps unfortunately, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone).

para.break: An essential in this matter relates to the way in which advice is tendered to both the government and the parliament on an independent cross‐sectoral basis. The abolition of NBEET is an important issue because it goes to the very basic issue of how well Austral ians, this parliament and the minister understand the need to address the crucial linkages between the nation's economic performance, its employment parameters and the implications that arise from those considerations for the role of the education and training sectors. That is essentially the conclusion that was reached by the Wiltshire review into NBEET, which was conducted in 1994.

speech.para: The Labor Party and the Australian Democrats have together presented a dissenting report on the amendments being proposed to the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill which seek to abolish a longstanding body—NBEET, the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. We believe that the proposed changes to the advisory mechanisms, including the abolition of NBEET, are wrong. We believe that the minister has conducted this in a manner which effectively closes down the operations of NBEET and its councils before the parliament has had an opportunity to deal with the relevant legislation. That was wrong. In my judgment, it was not within the law for her to undertake the closure of these bodies in the manner in which she did. The failure of the minister to set out the reasons for her decision was a contemptuous action by her in the way she effectively dismissed the chairs and members of this body's board and councils, which are protected by legislation. We also believe the government and the minister have failed to explain any meaningful strategy concerning the establishment of alternative advisory mechanisms.

It is with that in mind that we raise this in the context of DEETYA having done very well out of this decision, because it means they do not have any counterweight. They have no mechanisms available through formal legislative means to provide this parliament with counter‐advice on an independent and a cross‐sectoral basis. I think that is the problem with this. Why is cross‐sectoral independent advice so important? Quite clearly this government fears independent advice. Right across the board they are abolishing independent sources of advice in such a manner as would provide opportunities for the government and ministers to pick on a hand‐picked
basis appropriate people to tell them what they want to hear.

In education that is a particularly dangerous proposition. The complexities of the issues, the range of interest groups involved and the manner in which these interest groups are often at each other's throats mean it is extremely difficult for any government, but particularly this government given the minister's ignorance about the issues concerned, to be able to move through the differences that exist within this industry.

Why was NBEET so important in that regard? Because it provided a vehicle by which people from different sectors with different interests had to confront their prejudices. They were forced to come together and confront their prejudices in a manner which, in my opinion, led to a much better weighing and balancing of the various claims of the various interest groups and, in my judgment, facilitated a much more coherent policy approach. That is quite clearly absent, given that the government has proposed no viable means to provide for independent cross‐sectoral advice under its new arrangements.

Of course, the government is free to pick and choose what advice to call upon. I understand governments are entitled to pick and choose to act on advice, but I find it extraordinary that this government is so intent on cutting off from itself independent advice which may in fact save this country considerable difficulty in financial and, more importantly, in social terms. Getting it wrong in education has enormous implications for this country as a whole.

para.break: In the evidence presented to the committee, I note the speed and the alacrity with which DEET officials went about disbanding NBEET. One can understand why. DEET has for some time sought the removal of that independent cross-sectoral advice in such a way to make sure that it and of course the state governments become the key sources of advice on quite complicated matters. Bear in mind that this portfolio has $14 billion or thereabouts of expenditure per annum. Bear in mind the crucial role that this portfolio plays in terms of the development of Austral ian society, given the importance of education, training and employment.

speech.para: So, in effect, we rely entirely upon the actions of the state governments, made up of ministers whose idea of the long-term view is the end of their desk and whose idea of the Commonwealth's role in education, for instance, is that it should just sign the blank cheque and leave the rest to the states. We see appalling circumstances right around this country of the consequences of that sort of attitude, where they resent the involvement of the national government and the involvement of a coherent national policy framework.

If you leave it to the states, the parochial interests will always dominate over the national interest. The broader view will always be sacrificed to the short-term, narrow view in terms of the political interests of parochial state governments made up by and large of parochial state ministers.

To me this notion that somehow or other we hand over the money to the states and that premiers, if they so choose, can wallpaper their offices with it is a totally inappropriate means by which to run education and training policies. That is basically the situation that will arise under this new framework which this government is embarking upon. We are left with no other option but to conclude that this government will from time to time seek hand‐picked persons to provide the words of comfort that it seeks to resolve what are very complex issues.

Of particular concern to me is the way in which the school sector is effectively being locked out of the national policy process by the actions of this government to abolish this board. There is no vehicle for the sector to provide advice on an ongoing basis, to provide the institutional memory that is necessary to ensure the participation of teachers as well as parents in the formulation of national policy. That was quite clearly the view parents put to the committee and it is a view that quite clearly this government is not interested in. I think the bureaucracy does a very good job in many regards, but it should not be the sole source of advice on quite complex issues.

break.para: In relation to the amendments being proposed by the government, the main concerns raised by witnesses in the higher education sector and the Australian Research Council were the premature nature of the government's moves to introduce such measures and to provide for a legislative framework which had not allowed for appropriate or detailed consultation with the industry in such a manner which reflected a high degree of bad faith on behalf of the government with regards to the present and what I think ought to be regarded as proper consultative processes. When you add to that the demise of the School Council and the Language and Literacy Council, you see that there is a considerable loss of effectiveness, comprehensiveness and real quality in advice that has been provided by NBEET over the last few years. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

question.speaker: Brown, Sen Bob

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 23 August 1996:

question.para: Has the Government received any applications in 1996 from the Tasmanian Government or Forestry Tasmania for approval of forestry operations in areas other than those approved as part of the Interim Forest Agreement signed in January 1996; if so, what are the details of the applications and the areas to which they apply?

answer.speaker: Parer, Sen Warwick

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Yes. The Commonwealth has received a number of requests from Tasmania for approval of forestry operations in areas included in the Interim Forest Area under the Commonwealth‐Tasmanian Interim Forest Agreement (IFA) when it was signed in January.

Under the IFA, the Interim Forest Area is broadly defined as all public native forest areas available for harvesting which are not specified in Forestry Tasmania's Three Year Wood Production Plans for 1995‐96 to 1997‐98 (the WPP), as amended in accordance with Schedule 1 of the IFA. At this stage, no changes have been made to the IFA or its schedules. These requests are being considered by the Commonwealth in accordance with the provisions of the IFA.
The relevant provisions of the IFA under which applications to harvest within the Interim Forest Area or to amend the WPP have been made, and the areas (districts) involved are as follows.

(1) Clause 6 of the IFA permits completion of harvesting operations commenced before the IFA came into force, subject to case‐by‐case consideration by the Commonwealth, notwithstanding that the operations are in the Interim Forest Area. Earlier this year, the Commonwealth approved completion of operations in coupes in the Bass, Eastern Tiers, Huon and Murchison districts.

(2) Clause 7 of the IFA permits mining in the Interim Forest Area. In response to a request affecting an area roughly in the vicinity of St Valentine's peak, the Commonwealth agreed that salvage of wood, the felling of which was absolutely necessary to allow mining activities to proceed, was consistent with the intent of clause 7 of the IFA. Tasmania has asked that the Commonwealth also consent to salvaging of wood felled during upgrading of transmission lines in the Central Highlands.

(3) Clauses 12 to 15 of the IFA describe a process for reviewing the status of areas (as either included or excluded from the Interim Forest Area) in exceptional circumstances. Any changes must be by amendment to Schedule 1 of the IFA and must be consistent with the objectives of the agreement. Commonwealth officials have agreed in principle to a number of amendments to the WPP where the circumstances meet the requirements of clauses 12 and 12.1. The areas involved are in the Huon and Mersey districts. The Commonwealth is currently considering a request to review the status of a further set of areas, in the Bass, Circular Head, Derwent, Huon and Mersey districts, under this part of the IFA. This request is to both add and remove areas from the WPP.

(4) Clause 11 of the IFA provides for variation of the agreement, in writing. The Commonwealth is considering a number of changes to the status of areas requested by Tasmania which do not come within the above terms of the IFA. These affect areas in the Bass, Derwent, Eastern Tiers, Mersey and Murchison districts. Amendment of the agreement would be required for the requests to be met.
These proposed variations represent a net change of about 4 per cent of the total number of coupes included in the three year WPP.

Any variations to the IFA and its schedules must be in writing and will be agreed by the Prime Minister and Premier of Tasmania. All requests for changes to the Interim Forest Area or the IFA will be considered by the Commonwealth in light of the objectives of the agreement. Relevant Commonwealth agencies provide advice on the conservation values (including National Estate values) of the areas involved in a process mirroring the process by which the Interim Forest Area was initially established. Due consideration will be given to maintaining options for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system. Other considerations may include:
The need for the request to be met before the Regional Forest Agreement is finalised (June 1997);
The potential to remove equivalent areas from the WPP, thus the net change to the volume of wood harvested and the area and types of forest cut;
Other terms of the IFA, such as those requiring consistency of treatment between the States.

While the requests received to date have arisen from operational needs, the exceptional circumstances provisions also provide a mechanism whereby either party can seek to have the status of an area reviewed where conservation values are threatened or newly identified.
